description: Number of steps to compute n-th prime in PRIMEGAME (fast version).
references: D. Olivastro, Ancient Puzzles. Bantam Books, NY, 1993, p. 21.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
J. H. Conway, FRACTRAN: a simple universal programming language for arithmetic, in T. M. Cover and Gopinath, eds., Open Problems in Communication and Computation, Springer, NY 1987, pp. 4-26.
R. K. Guy, Conway's prime producing machine, Math. Mag. 56 (1983), no. 1, 26-33.
maple: with(numtheory): f:= proc(n) local l, b, d; l:= sort([divisors (n)[]]); b:= l[nops(l)-1]; n-1 +(6*n+2)*(n-b) +2*add(floor(n/d), d=b..n-1) end: a:= proc(n) option remember; `if`(n=1, f(2), a(n-1) +add(f(i), i=ithprime(n-1)+1..ithprime(n))) end: seq(a(n), n=1..40); # _Alois P. Heinz_, Aug 12 2009
mathematica: f[n_] := Module[{l, b, d}, l = Divisors [n]; b = l[[-2]]; n-1 + (6*n+2)*(n-b) + 2*Sum[Floor[n/d], {d, b, n-1}]]; a[n_] := a[n] = If[n == 1, f[2], a[n-1] + Sum[f[i], {i, Prime[n-1]+1, Prime[n]}]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 32}] (* _Jean-Fran√ßois Alcover_, Oct 04 2013, translated from Alois P. Heinz's Maple program *)
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
extensions: More terms from _Alois P. Heinz_, Aug 12 2009
